Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 Be signed and dated.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

Violation
Established?

ALLEGATION:
Facility has been operating out of ratio consistently and there is a concern for how it
impacts supervision and safety of the youth.
INVESTIGATION:
Interviews:
Complaint source was interviewed via telephone on June 13, 2022. Complaint
source reported there are two youth that need one to one support and there have
been only two staff working on the unit. These youth are Youth A and Youth B.
Complaint source reported there is a total of six youth currently on the unit.
Complaint source reported Youth A assaults other residents. The unit is typically out
of ratio on 1st and 3rd shift. Complaint source reported a supervisor will be on the unit
but will just sit in the office and not be on the floor with the youth.
2

Chief Administrator was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 13,
2022 and interviewed via telephone on June 21, 2022. When allegations were
reviewed with Chief Administrator, he reported Youth A is on a one-to-one status
when he needs the extra support and when staffing allows it. Chief Administrator
reported Youth A has been attending school off campus and not at Wedgwood but
recently the school year ended for summer vacation. Chief Administrator reported he
has put a hold on accepting new admissions onto this unit because they want to
make sure they remain in ratio. He reported he has not heard of any concerns of the
unit being out of ratio. During a phone interview on June 21, 2022, it was discussed
about the ratio issue on May 28, 2022. It was found the home had 5 youth at
nighttime and 1 staff member present where there should have been 2 staff
members. Chief Administrator reported the staff member that was scheduled called
off work at 10:30pm and due to the holiday weekend, it was a struggle to find
another staff member. It was reported that due to that late call off the staff member
was given disciplinary action. Chief Administered reported the facility has been
putting new plans in place for what to do if this was to happen again. He reported
recently the facility has implemented a meeting every Thursday with each home
supervisor across the agency to review scheduling and how to support one another.
This has been helpful to make sure coverage is taken care of at each home and the
supervisors are aware of what the needs are at each unit.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 13, 2022. Youth A
was working with Supervisor 1 when this consultant arrived. Youth A has limited
verbal skills and was able to say hi to this worker and note that he was happy.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 13, 2022.
Supervisor 1 reported currently there are 7 youth residing on the unit. They have a
ratio on 1 staff for every 2 youth during waking hours. Supervisor 1 reported the
schedule 4 staff during waking hours, so they stay within ratio and meet the needs of
Youth A’s one-to-one when needed. Supervisor 1 reported staffing has been difficult,
but it has been getting better as months go on. He reported overnights is sometimes
where they have the difficulty to make sure they have the two staff for ratio.
Supervisor 1 reported the unit is currently not taking any new admissions to make
sure they stay within ratio. Supervisor 1 reported when there is an open spot within
the schedule, they will pass that long to part time workers and on call workers. If no
one is able to pick up the shift, then himself or Supervisor 2 will pick up the shift.
Supervisor 1 reported he has a weekly meeting with other unit supervisors to talk
about their staffing schedules and behaviors on the units to see where support is
needed. He reported this has been extremely helpful when it comes to making sure
everyone is fully staffed. When asked if the unit has been out of ratio in the past
month, supervisor one reported he does not believe so. Supervisor 1 reported there
may have been on third shift over the holiday weekend when there was only one
staff member because the other third shift staff member called off minutes before
they were supposed to come in. He reported they attempted to fill the shift, but also
3

other units were struggling with staffing and there was no coverage found. The on-
call supervisor was already covering for another unit.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 13, 2022.
Supervisor 2 reported Youth A is supposed to have a one-to-one staffing during
waking hours and when he is not in school. She reported this is also on an as
needed basis. Typically, they will add in a one-to-one staffing for Youth A when they
have a new admission since Youth A’s behaviors increase when there is a change to
the unit. Supervisor 2 reported this is Youth A’s first week of summer vacation.
Supervisor 2 reported the ratio on the unit is one staff for every two youth. She
reported she works with Supervisor 1 on creating the weekly schedule and has four
staff scheduled during the day and two staff scheduled at over nights. Supervisor 2
reported staffing has been a struggle with the pandemic. She reported she does
weekly supervision with her staff to do a check in and focuses on how their self-care
plan is going. She reported she has three full time overnight workers to help
maintain the ratio. Supervisor 2 reported sometimes they cannot maintain ratio
because they help support other units when there is a crisis. She reported that when
staff are unable to fill in the open shifts on the schedule that herself or Supervisor 1
will take on an extra shift. She reported someone called off this morning and she
picked up the shift so that they could be in ratio.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 13, 2022. Staff 1
reported she has just come back from medical leave on May 16, 2022. She reported
that she has been working both morning and evening shifts. Staff 1 reported there
has been a staffing shortage all around the facility and the supervisors do what they
can to fill the spots. She reported the unit typically runs with four staff working during
waking hours unless the kids are in off ground school then it less. She reported
sometimes a staff member will call off last minute and the supervisors try to find
someone to fill in the spot. Staff 1 reported the unit has had only three staff working
a shift once but could not remember the amount of youth living on the unit at the
time. Staff 1 believed they were in ratio at the time. She reported this morning
someone called off and Supervisor 2 filled in to maintain ratio.
Documents Reviewed:
 VanderArk Program Statement- The program statement for the facility reports
the day time staffing ratio is one staff member to every two youth and the
nighttime staffing ratio is one staff member to every four youth.
 Contract between Michigan Department of Health and Human Services and
West License- The contract states the contractor must maintain a minimum of
one on-duty direct care worker for every two youth during wake hours. The
contractor must maintain a minimum of one-duty direct care worker for every four
youth during sleeping hours.
 Staff scheduled for week of 05/29/2022-06/18/2022: The schedule notes there
were six shifts noting the person who was scheduled to work was out sick.
4

Meaning there was only three staff working on the shift with the youth. There
were notes of coverage for each shift.
 VanderArk Daily Census for 05/16/22-06/16/22: The daily census notes the
daily number of youths residing on the unit during the day and night. There are
notes within the census that documents when a youth is on an overnight home
pass. The range of youth being on shift was 4-7 youth at a time.
 VanderArk Timesheet for third shift employees for 05/16/22-06/16/22- The
time sheets show that all shifts were covered during waking hours for the youth
to maintain appropriate ratio. There was one third shift on 05/22/2022 where
there were 5 youth residing on the unit and 1 staff working.
 Youth A MiSACWIS Approved Placement Exception Request (PER) - The
PER notes the youth is approved for one-to-one supervision at West Campus for
the period of time from 04/12/22-07/10/22 for up to 12 hours per day based on
the need at the facility.
 1:1 Weekly Tracking Sheet for Youth A dated 5/31/2022-06/12/2022- Youth A
received one to one supervision on 05/31/22, 06/03/22, 06/04/22,
06/07/22,06/8/22, 06/9/22,06/10/22, 06/11/22, 06/12/22. The days one to one
supervision was not provided was 06/01/22, 06/02/22, 06/05/22, 06/06/22.
 Email from Youth A’s foster care worker dated 6/13/2022- Youth A’s foster
care worker reported, “It (one-to-one staffing) is based on Youth A’s needs.
Specifically, he struggles with change in schedule and transitioning from one
activity to another. In the summer his schedule variates more frequently with
trips, outings, and field trips much more that during school. This is sometimes
difficult requiring the 1:1. I have had no concerns with staff at Wedgwood. They
communicate often and have always been available when I drop by for an
unannounced visit. Both the office staff and direct staff work together for me to
have my private meeting with Youth A and to view his room.”
 Youth B MiSACWIS Approved Placement Exception Request (PER) - The
PER notes the youth is approved for one-to-one supervision at West Campus for
the period of time from 02/22/22-05/22/22 for up to 12 hours per day based on
the need at the facility. The PER request for 05/23/2022-08/2022 does not
request continuation of one-to-one supervision. The one-to-one supervision
ended on 05/23/22.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4127 Staff-to-resident ratio.
(1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-
to-resident ratio formula for direct care workers.
5

ANALYSIS: The facility was found in violation due to having one third shift
where the unit was out of ratio over the past month.
Consultantion:
It is recommended for the home supervisors to continue their
Thursday meetings and to talk about what to do when a staff
member calls off for third shift at the time they are supposed to
be at work. It is recommended for the facility to follow the plans
they have set in place with hiring a third shift floater to help
support the units on campus in needs. It is recommended for
home supervisors to be aware to call upper leadership for
support when staffing is out of ratio to make sure coverage can
be secured.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, I recommend no change to the
license status of this child caring institution.
